The year when expanded recommendations for early allergen introduction were issued, leading to increased adoption and measurable declines in peanut allergy rates among children.
The year when updated clinical guidance was published, reinforcing the recommendation to introduce allergenic foods (like peanuts) between 4 and 6 months of age, without prior screening.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The decade-long period during which early peanut introduction practices have been adopted and proven effective in reducing food allergy incidence, particularly peanut allergies in young children.

keyTakeAways: Peanut allergies in children have declined significantly in the U.S. since 2015, with a 27% drop after 2015 and over 40% decline after 2017 due to early allergen introduction guidelines.

The LEAP trial, led by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, showed that early introduction of peanuts reduced allergy risk by over 80%, with protection lasting into adolescence in about 70% of children.
Only about 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists initially followed the expanded 2017 guidelines, indicating slow adoption due to confusion and uncertainty.
The new research analyzes electronic health records from pediatric practices and shows that early exposure to peanuts is now being adopted and has a measurable public health impact.
About 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015, highlighting the real-world success of the public health strategy.

Current guidance (updated in 2021) recommends introducing peanuts and other allergens between 4 and 6 months of age, without prior testing, and with small amounts of peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, or tree nut butters as safe options.
Advocacy groups like Food Allergy Research & Education (FARE) support early introduction as a proven way to reduce allergy prevalence nationwide.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after a landmark study showed that introducing peanut products to infants as early as 4 months reduces the risk of developing peanut allergies, new research confirms that this public health strategy has led to a measurable decline in allergy rates. Since 2015, peanut allergy rates in children under 3 have dropped by over 27%, and by over 40% after expanded guidelines in 2017. The research, led by Dr. David Hill and based on electronic health records, shows that about 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since the guidelines were adopted. The key scientific foundation comes from the LEAP trial by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, which demonstrated over an 80% reduction in allergy risk through early exposure. Despite initial slow adoption due to confusion among medical professionals, the strategy is now being widely implemented, with current guidelines (updated in 2021) recommending early, safe exposure to allergens like peanuts, milk, and tree nuts. Advocacy groups like FARE support this shift as a major step toward reducing food allergy prevalence.
title: Early Peanut Introduction Reduces Allergy Rates in U.S. Children
